title: Vietnam horns in on African blood ivory maket
text:
Vietnam horns in on African blood ivory maket   
By Apolinari Tairo, eTN Tanzania Correspondent | Aug 26, 2015 eTN   
TANZANIA (eTN) - Customs authorities in Vietnam seized this week Monday, more than two tons of blood ivory from Africa, just a month since Swiss custom officials intercepted a large haul of elephant tusks on transit from Tanzania to China. 
Reports from Hanoi said the ivory shipment was disguised as logs of timber from Nigeria in West Africa and was seized just eight days after confiscating another shipment of elephant tusks weighing nearly a ton from Mozambique. 
A Vietnamese customs department official said the ivory cargo was worth about US$4.4 million and was posted to the same company listed as the receiver for nearly a ton of elephant tusks and rhinoceros horn from Mozambique that was discovered on the 13th of this month. 
The seizure of ivory from Africa has been a clear indication of the massive poaching of elephants and rhinoceros on this continent, posing a threat to their total extinction. 
But the illicit trade of blood ivory and rhino horn from Africa to Asia has grown with rising prosperity creating demand in Vietnam and China due to corrupt government officials in Africa’s wildlife conservation parks, while abject poverty among local communities has been driving the locals to cooperate with illegal wildlife traders on the poaching of elephants. 
A rising demand for elephant ivory and rhino horns in East Asia has led to an epidemic of poaching across the whole African continent. 
According to data compiled by the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), also known as the World Wildlife Fund in the US and Canada, about 22,000 elephants were killed in Africa from 2012, out of a remaining population of around 500,000. Major ivory seizures between 2013 and 2015 are estimated at 50 tons, a record that indicates danger facing the African jumbos. 
Rhino populations are even more at risk, with most killed in South Africa and which boasts of breeding a population of about 25,000 rhinos in highly-protected parks. 
A recent report released by the African Wildlife Foundation (AWF) showed that Tanzania lost 60 percent of its elephants in the past five years. The country had as low as 43,330 jumbos in 2014 from 109,051 in 2009. 
According to AWF, a single elephant can generate US$1.6 million in tourism revenue if left to live out its normal lifespan. 
It is estimated that 65,721 elephants were killed in Tanzania during the past five years, making this African elephant state being dubbed as “Elephant slaughterhouse.”
